reviewText: the fans know the story and  by now even the most casual among them know that when the Boys left Roach for "higher endeavours", it resulted in a stream of strange, dark passages into B-movie land, at the hand of washed up directors and 3rd rate writers, who had no apparent desire to let the greatest team of all make even passable films.this Reviewer enjoys THE DANCING MASTERS, a mixed up but funny comedy, very much in trheir wheelhouse. it even had Margaret Dumont and (Roachs') Charles Rogers, on the scene.two years later, Stan and Ollie completed their final film for Fox and though they look tired, one must assume they did not *hate* the results> it's 100% comedy, with plenty of L & H-isms, camera looks, kooky sight gags, and reasonably well set up slapstick sequences. the storyline is predictable but for the first time in a long time, it's not a meandering melange of stuff from the past, not improved at all.Stan is a look-alike for a famous matador....the real guy is not available for the big fight. Guess what happens?
summary: their most coherent and funniest in years
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm sure many L & H fans will agree that it is a pleasure to watch Stan & Ollie, in the '40s, unencumbered by the Hollywood formula Goofy-Guys-Help-The-Lovers-And-Get-Into-Mischief, and really do their thing  - to a certain extent. Although they look a little tired and the picture  could have been much funnier, it remains a respectable later effort.
Title: N/A

reviewText: By far the best film L&H made in the 40's is a pleasure to watch.  Fans will recognize most of the routines, but will have lots of fun seeing the boys go through a plot that actually suits them.  Certainly the best of a poor lot of films, fans and kids will love it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Most of Laurel & Hardy's later films had confining scripts that didn't give the team much room to do their stuff. "The Bullfighters" is a happy exception, with funny gags and familiar pantomime. Stan Laurel  co-wrote and co-directed without screen credit, so fans are taking a second  look (or even a first look) at this forgotten comedy. The boys' precision  timing is as sharp as ever, and they're in practically every scene. The  video transfer is excellent.
summary: Laurel & Hardy are the whole show in this hour of fun.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Bullfighters" (1945) was Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy's best effort for 20th Century-Fox. It also marked the comedy team's premature farewell to Hollywood - not surprising, since the studio system offered Stan and Ollie little in the way of creative freedom. (By  comparison, their final film, the 1951 French production "Atoll  K," was a more adventurous enterprise.) Nevertheless, there are some  inventive routines in this Mexican escapade, with a memorable closing shot  that is a nostalgic throwback to the team's two-reelers at Hal Roach.  Admittedly, "The Bullfighters" is not a classic, but it remains a  vast improvement over the blandness of "Great Guns" and "Air  Raid Wardens."
summary: Laurel and Hardy's Last Hollywood Film
Title: N/A
